comments.commentBody:
Why don't you try Lyle's Golden Syrup? It may be British, not Swedish, but should do the job. Most upscale grocers in Manhattan should have it.
Bon appetit!
Tate & Lyle Golden Syrup is an English treat, not Swedish. The can is visible in the photograph.
We eat tons of cabbage in my family. I love this! I recommend trying it with curry as well.

My mother, a native of Sighet, in Transylvania, was determined to feed us true American food. It was only when we visited with her older sisters, maiden aunts, that I got to taste the special flavors of Europe.  Among my favorites was "kropletzlach," a combination of caramelized onions, cabbage, and garlic served over egg noodles.  As an adult, my maiden aunts and mother relegated to memory, I have conjured up those long-forgotten flavors by baking trays of cabbage, onions, mushrooms, garlic and sometimes red pepper.  I have been known to serve this over pasta or farro, often accompanied by whole milk Greek yogurt. It's always a hit.
Sounds yummy. I will have to give it try, but without the pork.

This looks fabulous! I'll try this with a substitution of Homemade Worcestershire Sauce because store-bought Worcestershire Sauce contains free glutamates, which can be commonly referred to as MSG. Of the published ingredients many contain such free glutamates. Barley Malt Vinegar, Molasses, Spice, and Flavourings all have a high likelihood of being so. As I am highly sensitive to MSG I must avoid it. But I love the flavor of Worcestershire Sauce. So . . . I found a reasonable homemade version at food.com. I know it won't be as tasty as Lea & Perrins', but the home made version will allow me to sleep through the night.

Homemade Worcestershire Sauce
Ingredients
• 1/2 cup apple cider vinegar
• 2 tablespoons low sodium soy sauce
• 2 tablespoons water
• 1 tablespoon brown sugar
• 1/4 teaspoon ground ginger
• 1/4 teaspoon mustard powder
• 1/4 teaspoon onion powder
• 1/4 teaspoon garlic powder
• 1/8 teaspoon cinnamon
• 1/8 teaspoon black pepper

Directions
Place all ingredients in a medium saucepan and stir thoroughly. Bring to a boil, stirring constantly. Simmer 1 minute. Cool.
Store in the refrigerator.

Sorry, I just noticed that soy sauce is in that recipe for Worcestershire Sauce. I cannot use that either because it is high in free glutamate. So, I think I'll just omit it and make the whole thing this way.

I'very always thought the key to Worcestershire sauce was tamarind - you can buy tamarind paste or tamarind water to make it easier. It might be enough on its own in this recipe without trying to recreate the sauce.

This dish sounds wonderful, especially the caramelized cabbage. However, I'm a vegetarian. Is there any way to make this dish vegetarian (aside from vegetarian ground meat substituted in place of the meat)? Thanks.

Mmmm, cabbage! Though red is my favorite, some green cabbage, slowly cooked to goldness, without any added sugar, a little caraway for "northern Europe" flavor, with slow cooker baked ham, done in beer (Ricardo Larivée) that gets a kind of smokedmeat/pastrami texture. Now that's a meal for March, until we get all those new greens we are expecting very soon to come by!
Bon appétit!

I made this today... Very tasty but I had a lot of liquid.  Probably because my "small" onion was not small enough ( a weight would be helpful) and I did not completely reduce the cabbage down prior to adding to the mix.  The umami flavor mentioned by ace Scandinavian Chef is most true.   I used  Black Strap Molasses but the result not overly sweet nor had a molasses flavor.   One more thing a 3lb head a cabbage requires a very big pan.  I had a 12" and it was a mess. I had to transfer over to a wok.
Loved reading the article!  The details of this dish were very entertaining and interesting too.  Kalpudding is on my list!
Did her thumb recover?
Totally. She is well now, though her recovery was difficult.

It surprises me that the doctor's at her home hospital didn't seem to have kept track of the possibility of fungal infections in an immune compromised patient, such as fungal infections. I take quite a bit of immune suppressants to control an aggressive autoimmune syndrome. Maybe I have attentive doctors, but the management of my treatment has always been very careful. Enough medicines to keep the syndrome from progressing, but not enough to risk any kind of infection. It's not an easy balancing act for sure, and I do get infections from time to time.

1) I'm not sure why the woman can't treat her psoriatic arthritis with drugs that suppress the immune system. The histoplasmosis has been successfully treated. Perhaps the tradeoff is giving up the gardening and bird feeding?
2) Mayo's a fine hospital with outstanding resident and attending physicians. But did her primary care provider really have to send her on a 600 mile shlep across 4 states to Minnesota? There are fine hospitals in Missouri. Barnes-Jewish Hospital affiliated with Washington University's outstanding medical school comes to mind. I'm sure Kansas City has something similar. One would think they would recognize the dermatological manifestations of histoplasmosis seeing as they're closer to the endemic area. That was one prescient senior resident in Minneapolis though. Had she not recalled a similar case seen previously I presume the dermatologist would have recognized it.

This may be in the ballpark, but not real close to home plate, but part of Mayo's success is the keeping of historical medical records utilizing a cataloging system that could be crossed referenced to aid in the diagnosis of medical conditions, including those that were relatively rare or were 'cousins' to something that had been previously seen, diagnosed, and treated.  I believe those records were kept in the Plummer Building and of course, were originally paper records.  I learned this several years ago when our son was being seen at Mayo for an unusual neurological condition.
No fun at all, Doctor. What happened to waiting till we, the subscribers, tried figuring it out?
I agree! I really miss the Think Like A Doctor column. Is it gone for good?
How do you take your cumin and how much?  How long before u could tell it was making a difference!  Do u have arthritis in your finger joints?

Why was this woman on powerful immune suppressing drugs for years?  Her doctor should have been monitoring her for infection given the medications he/she prescribed.  Too many times patients are prescribed meds and stay on them for way too long.
Mayo doesn't have an ER...so they sent her 600 miles away to be admitted to St. Mary's in Rochester? I am glad it worked out but the decision making on her original physicians' part was lacking.
Not true. Mayo in Rochester has a state of the art level one trauma rated emergency room.
Available to those who can afford it

Is this a joke?
As an RN of more than 40 years, the least several decades in ICU, it's clear that the woman was septic and a sepsis protocol should have been initiated. A gangrenous foul-smelling wound, fever, chills, disorientation, confusion. Clear indications of sepsis. Immuno-suppressed on top of all that? Please, Lord, spare me from encountering any of the MD's involved in this scenario.
Regardless of the causative agent, the protocol should have been started as soon as the woman presented with her symptoms in the ER. We treat broadly first and then work out a more fine-tuned treatment regimen once we isolate the organism responsible for the sepsis.
And what was with the "Mayo Clinic" directive from the first doc? That ten-hour drive could very well have been lethal.
Even a first year resident should be aware of the signs and symptoms of early sepsis.
Pathetic sequence of events bordering on (no, I would say clearly entering the realm of) negligence if not outright malpractice.
People without medical training never won. That got old. It's fine without the contest.

While 'the Mayo' has a well deserved excellent reputation, this lady's internist should have told her daughter to take her to any of the 4 major medical centers in Missouri:  St. John's Mercy (68 miles from Joplin), University of Missouri-Kansas City (158 miles), University of Missouri-Columbia (236 miles) or Washington University Medical Center (284 miles).  She probably drove right past UMKC on her way north to Mayo.  Glad everything turned out alright.

So basically her problem was a side effect of immune suppressing drugs. Instead of figuring out the root cause of her psoriatic arthritis, here take a drug. Oh whoops it caused another problem. I have psoriasis and based on my experience, dietary changes (esp no dairy) and regular exposure to sunlight or light tanning (to keep vit D levels up) completely eradicate my psoriasis. This poor woman, she might not have had to suffer if some medical personnel along the way had talked to her about her diet and other lifestyle changes.

I have now read 2 stories in 2 days of people being on autoimmune drugs and ending up either not needing it in the first place or managing without it in this case. So are the immune suppressing drugs way too dangerous to prescribe?
No, I (for one) and transplant patients survive because of them. However, as medicines they require detailed and careful management.
They pay for the Mayo Clinic the same way you pay for any doctor's visit. The Clinic accepts insurance. Or they pay cash if they don't have insurance.
